questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Drive alone.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Five to six seconds
questions.answerC: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: When using road speed to know when to switch gears, you should:
questions.answerA: Learn what speeds each gear is good for and shift up when necessary.
questions.answerB: Watch other vehicles and try to keep pace.
questions.answerC: Watch other trucks and shift when they shift.
questions.answerD: Use the speed limit as a guide.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When making a lane change, your turn signal:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if there is traffic present.
questions.answerC: Should only be used between dusk and dawn.
questions.explanation: You must always properly signal before turning or changing lanes.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Decline transporting the load.
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.answerC: Date of packing.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerB: Black ice
questions.answerC: Green ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.answerC: You should look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerC: The brakes are new.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: When driving, knowing what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Use your mirrors frequently to help you remain aware of your surroundings.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.answerC: Stay in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Travel faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should always scan the road for potential hazards. Formulate plans for how to deal with the hazards if they develop into emergencies.

questions.question: You will often have to drive your vehicle under bridges and overpasses. If approaching such an opening, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the posted clearance height is accurate.
questions.answerB: Assume the posted clearance height is inaccurate.
questions.answerC: Measure the height of the opening before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Do not assume that posted height clearances are accurate. If the road was repaved after the sign was posted, or if there is packed snow on the ground, the actual height of the opening may be different than what is indicated. If you are not confident that your vehicle will be able to safely clear an upcoming bridge or overpass, you should slow down and find another path, if possible.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerC: Excess sleep
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: All trailers made after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.answerB: While driving.
questions.answerC: After driving.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.answerB: Prevent a rollover.
questions.answerC: Make turns more dangerous.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay at your current speed.
questions.answerC: Further reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.answerB: A flag.
questions.answerC: Hydraulic brakes.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: Bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: Only once temperatures drop significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: After all other surfaces.
questions.answerC: Before other surfaces.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the roadway. Be particularly careful on bridges when temperatures are close to the freezing point.

questions.question: During a trip, gauges are:
questions.answerB: The only way a driver can learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A way to learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly check the gauge and instrument panels, mirrors, tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerC: The windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine compartment, be sure to check the oil level; the radiator coolant level and the condition of the hoses; the power steering fluid level and the condition of the hoses, if applicable; the windshield washer fluid level; the battery connections, fluid level, and tie-downs; the automatic transmission fluid level; and the condition and tightness of the belts. Additionally, check for any leaks in the engine compartment and cracked or worn electrical wiring insulation.

questions.question: What is the only way to sober up after drinking?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Wait.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be increased through tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to wait for the alcohol to be removed from your system.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Engine oil.
questions.answerC: Time of day.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include your vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Increases your braking distance.
questions.answerC: Creates a loud squeaking noise when being used.
questions.answerD: Helps to ensure control while braking.
questions.explanation: ABS increases a driver's control during braking. It will not necessarily change the distance needed for a vehicle to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Assume it does have ABS.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: When loading a tank, space should be left for outage. What is outage?
questions.answerB: Space for expanding liquids
questions.answerC: Space for additional fuel
questions.answerD: A place for luggage and personal items
questions.explanation: Liquids expand when warmed, so a tank carrying liquid must also contain additional space to accommodate for this expansion. The extra space is known as "outage."

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: The cause of the "crack-the-whip" effect.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by one tractor.
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect is a result of rearward amplification. If not properly handled, a trailer can tip over due to rearward amplification.

questions.question: ____ cannot be transported on a bus in a space occupied by people.
questions.answerB: Radioactive materials
questions.answerC: Medical supplies
questions.explanation: While some hazardous materials may be transported by bus under specific conditions, labeled radioactive materials must never be carried in the space occupied by people.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge with a green light:
questions.answerB: You may proceed without stopping.
questions.answerC: You must wait for the light to change to yellow.
questions.explanation: A bus does not need to stop before crossing a drawbridge controlled by a green signal light. The driver should still slow down and verify that it is safe before crossing.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Use both side mirrors.
questions.answerC: Not use a helper.
questions.explanation: When backing a truck, always use the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have someone help you whenever possible.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerB: It is likely broken.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: If a tire rim is damaged, it should be:
questions.answerB: Welded to repair the damage.
questions.answerC: Replaced.
questions.answerD: Put on the axle farthest from the driver.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are not safe.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead of you:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to make a plan to avoid an upcoming hazard.
questions.answerB: Is not encouraged as it distracts you from driving.
questions.answerC: Is only important when traveling in congested traffic.
questions.explanation: Always watch for hazards on the road ahead. Doing this will allow you time to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: A bus driver is:
questions.answerA: Exempt from wearing a seat belt.
questions.answerB: Only required to wear a seat belt if the passengers have seat belts.
questions.answerC: Required to wear a seat belt at all times.
questions.answerD: Not required to wear a seat belt, but is encouraged to do so.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus should be equipped with a seat belt. A driver is always required to wear a seat belt while driving a bus.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive in the right lane.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.answerB: Black ice.
questions.answerC: Green ice.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: When using your mirrors, you should frequently look at your tires to:
questions.answerB: See if the tires are rolling properly.
questions.answerC: See if the tread is sufficient.
questions.answerD: Get a sense of the size of the tire in relation to other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Check your tires regularly when looking in your mirrors. This helps ensure that you will notice a tire fire, if one should happen. Tire fires may occur when a tire is under-inflated, if dual tires are touching, or if the tires are otherwise overheated.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.answerC: 75 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerB: When making a turn.
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Take drugs to keep awake.
questions.answerC: Stop and take a nap.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are very far off course.
questions.answerC: You should pull up to reposition the vehicle as needed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, you should pull up to reposition your vehicle as needed.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: If your coolant level is found to be low, you should:
questions.answerB: Add more coolant.
questions.answerC: Add engine oil.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things. In both cold and hot weather, it is important that the engine have enough coolant.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Yawning repeatedly or rubbing eyes
questions.answerC: Staying in your lane
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: Should never be done the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be done in the same order.
questions.answerC: Do not need to be done if the driver is familiar with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection should be completed in the same order every time. This will make it easier for you to learn all of the steps and will make it less likely that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Start from any position.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: What is Gross Combination Weight?
questions.answerA: The total weight of the powered unit, trailer, and cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a single vehicle without its load
questions.answerC: The maximum weight allowed by the manufacturer
questions.explanation: Gross Combination Weight (GCW) is the total weight of a powered unit, its trailer(s), and the cargo being carried.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When using a mirror, you should:
questions.answerB: Stare at the mirror for a long time.
questions.answerC: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: When making mirror checks, you should look at the mirrors fairly quickly. If you spend too much time looking in a mirror, you may travel a substantial distance down the road without seeing what is coming up ahead.

questions.question: When passengers have carry-on baggage, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Leave the items leaning against the rear exit door.
questions.answerB: Leave the items near the front door.
questions.answerC: Secure the items in a manner that allows easy access to all exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should never be allowed to leave baggage in the aisle or doorway of a bus. All luggage and cargo must be positioned in a manner that ensures riders are able to exit by any window or door in an emergency.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate your brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get their attention.
questions.explanation: To let drivers behind you know that you plan to slow down, lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to flash your brake lights. It is important to communicate your intentions to other drivers.

questions.question: If being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Try to let the other vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, avoid making quick changes in speed and open up your following distance. This will make it easier for the tailgater to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only needed for interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are very far off course.
questions.answerC: You should pull up to reposition the vehicle as needed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, you should pull up to reposition your vehicle as needed.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.answerC: You should never swerve.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: What is the only way to sober up after drinking?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Wait.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be increased through tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to wait for the alcohol to be removed from your system.

questions.question: A vehicle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Spare electrical fuses.
questions.answerC: Warning devices for a parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When starting an engine, warning lights and buzzers should:
questions.answerB: Flicker occasionally.
questions.answerC: Turn off right away.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.answerB: The mechanic
questions.answerC: The owner
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of a potentially drunk driver?
questions.answerA: They are staying in their traffic lane.
questions.answerB: They are driving a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: They are stopping without a reason.
questions.answerD: They have alcohol-related bumper stickers on their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs that a driver may be impaired include that they are having trouble staying in their lane, they are having trouble maintaining an appropriate driving speed, or they are stopping without a clear reason.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is like:
questions.answerB: Flying.
questions.answerC: Sleeping.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is similar to water skiing: your vehicle's tires glide along the road on a film of water without having traction with the surface of the road.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.answerB: 2 psi
questions.answerC: 3 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.answerB: Dual air brakes
questions.answerC: Triple air brakes
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerB: Bluetooth.
questions.answerC: GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Fills the tires.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.answerB: Free of oil.
questions.answerC: Soft.
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: The rods in S-cam brakes move the slack adjusters when air pressure is added to the brake chambers. This air pressure is added to the chambers when the driver:
questions.answerB: Uses the emergency brake.
questions.answerC: Uses the trailer hand valve.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: If you’re driving and the ABS warning light comes on, it means:
questions.answerB: The ABS has just been activated.
questions.answerC: The ABS is not working properly.
questions.answerD: The ABS needs to be activated.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to alert the driver if something is wrong with the braking system. If these lights activate, the driver may have lost ABS on one or more wheels.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.answerB: Brakes overheat.
questions.answerC: Brakes are too cold.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerB: Immediately stop driving.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: Four tanks
questions.answerC: Six tanks
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.answerB: 12 minutes.
questions.answerC: Three minutes.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with a single air brake system, after the engine is at operating rpms, the pressure in the air system should generally build from 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: Manual air tank drains should be:
questions.answerA: Opened to drain the tanks after each day.
questions.answerB: Left open while driving.
questions.answerC: Sealed with glue.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.answerB: Chocks.
questions.answerC: Foundation brakes.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: Five inches
questions.answerC: One inch
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: More than two inches
questions.answerC: Up to five inches
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerC: Look at the tires.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.answerC: To transport hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.answerC: Phone a mechanic while driving.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerB: Are only required on trailers.
questions.answerC: Are required on tractors.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: The safety valve located on the first tank opens:
questions.answerB: If there is too little pressure.
questions.answerC: If there is too much pressure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the first tank that receives compressed air has a safety valve that releases air if the pressure gets too high. It is usually set to open at 150 psi. If the valve must open, there is a fault in the system that should be repaired by a mechanic.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle equipped with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal up.
questions.answerC: Pull out the air brake knob.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, you should simply press the brake pedal down.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Shortens brake response time.
questions.answerC: Provides less control.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.answerB: Parking brakes
questions.answerC: Air brakes
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.answerB: One quarter
questions.answerC: One third
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: What happens if brakes become too hot?
questions.answerB: They will harden.
questions.answerC: They may stop working.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick in to cool the brakes
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they may overheat and stop working. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerB: Landing gear.
questions.answerC: Air brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.answerB: A lock
questions.answerC: A trap door
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.answerB: 25 psi
questions.answerC: 50 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: On newer vehicles, how do you put on the parking brake?
questions.answerA: Move a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Push in the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pull out the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerD: Pull up on the steering column.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The knob is pulled out to set the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.answerC: 150 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerB: 50 psi
questions.answerC: 75 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Prohibited on large vehicles.
questions.answerC: Only effective in poor weather.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerB: Only required when transporting liquids.
questions.answerC: Required to transport both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a tank endorsement is required to operate a tank vehicle that is used to haul either liquids or gases.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.answerC: Once a month
questions.explanation: In an air brake system with manually operated drains, the tanks should be drained at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: In a combination rig, it is best to make:
questions.answerB: Sharp turns.
questions.answerC: Quick accelerations.
questions.explanation: When driving a combination vehicle, it is important to brake well in advance and look far ahead of your vehicle to avoid the need for sudden stops. Making habits of these actions will help you prevent your trailer from jackknifing.

questions.question: What is off-tracking?
questions.answerA: When a vehicle’s front wheels follow a different path than its rear wheels
questions.answerB: When a vehicle's wheels all follow the exact same path
questions.answerC: When a load shifts during a turn
questions.answerD: When a vehicle's wheels run over a curb during a turn
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is known as off-tracking, or "cheating."

questions.question: When braking while pulling a trailer equipped with anti-lock brakes, you should:
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the brakes kick in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would without anti-lock brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: A driver should test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Unlocking the trailer doors.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Pushing in the trailer air supply control will:
questions.answerB: Deactivate the air brakes.
questions.answerC: Prevent the vehicle from skidding.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: When should the trailer hand valve be used?
questions.answerA: Only when the trailer is carrying a load
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer’s brakes
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will often continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerB: The trailer may disengage.
questions.answerC: The trailer may swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the cab and call for help.
questions.answerB: Exit the cab and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Motion for another driver to push your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify service lines?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Blue
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerB: Have reduced braking capabilities.
questions.answerC: Will not rollover.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: Combination vehicles need extra space on the road because they:
questions.answerA: Drive more slowly than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are heavier than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Need more space to turn and stop than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.answerC: Emergency air line.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.answerB: Apply the trailer emergency brakes.
questions.answerC: Prevent a skid.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve will close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer will detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Before beginning a trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the service line valve open.
questions.answerB: Remove the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerB: Drivers turn too slowly.
questions.answerC: It is raining.
questions.explanation: Rollovers occur when drivers turn or change lanes too quickly.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.answerB: A three-axle tractor
questions.answerC: A bobtail tractor
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.answerC: May be easier to steer during turns.
questions.explanation: Positioning the weight of a load on one side of a trailer may cause the trailer to lean to that side, increasing the risk of a rollover during turns and lane changes.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: When testing ____, you should apply your vehicle's brakes with the hand control while moving the vehicle forward slowly.
questions.answerB: The emergency braking system
questions.answerC: The trailer service brakes
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Glad hands can be connected to any other glad hands.
questions.answerC: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.answerB: Cause steering problems.
questions.answerC: Cause braking problems.
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: If you are backing and the trailer begins to drift off-course, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Place cargo high.
questions.answerC: Keep cargo loose.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.answerB: Help you drive faster.
questions.answerC: Make turns more dangerous.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.answerC: Unsafe to drive.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: If you are backing and become unsure about your path of travel, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop and get out to look.
questions.answerC: Continue backing, but more slowly than before.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of your path while you are driving in reverse, you should stop, exit the vehicle, and recheck your path of travel.

questions.question: Before beginning a trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the service line valve open.
questions.answerB: Remove the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Spread out in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Cargo weight should be evenly distributed within a trailer to reduce the risk of a rollover. Do not place too much weight on one side of a trailer.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must first turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerC: To the left.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle without a trailer, a driver must turn the vehicle in the direction that they want to go. However, when backing with a trailer, the driver must begin by turning in the opposite direction. Once the trailer starts to turn, they should turn the wheel in the other direction to follow the trailer.

questions.question: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the cab and call for help.
questions.answerB: Exit the cab and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Motion for another driver to push your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: Operating a combination vehicle usually requires ­­­­­____ operating a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.answerC: More skill than
questions.answerD: Exactly the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more skill to drive than single vehicles. Combination vehicles are usually longer and heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollovers.

questions.question: How many air lines does a combination vehicle have?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.
